content.description:
Immediately left of Faulty Mood (right of Escaping the Torch). Start below a shallow roof, clip a bolt and pull up and over to establish on the face. Clip another bolt about 8 feet higher. Climb the crack system up and slightly right, and then back left toward another bolt that leads past a steep section to small roof. Continue up past another bolt to the anchors.   

  Named for the reverse and downclimb strategy by AMH during the ground up FA up to the crux protected by the third bolt. After placing two sketchy nuts and suffering from forearm burn, AMH reversed and reached the top by climbing the chimney past the tree. Addition of the bolt makes the crux a steep and fun section slightly overhung. Protects well.
content.protection: Single rack up to one inch.
content.location: Just to the right of the wide crack. See route map.

content.description: Start 10 feet left of Corner Fault and about the same right of Faulty Mood. Climb the bolted face to the roof. Pull the roof and head up and slightly left to the chain anchors. It is a nice line, dammit. Named for the running discussion between us about what makes a nice line.
content.protection: 4 bolts with standard hangers and biners.
content.location: Middle of the wall, clearing the roof.

content.description: Start behind a small tree at a bolt. Climb the slightly diagonal crack to the roof, clipping one bolt along the way. Pull the roof at the obvious crack, taking the right-most crack of two that leads to the upper roof, which is significantly easier. Pull the upper roof to the anchors off right. Named for DASs mood that morning.
content.protection: 2 bolts and small to medium cams with some stoppers to protect the crux roof.
content.location: About 25 feet left of Corner Fault, just to the right of Reverse Fault.

content.description: Ten feet right of Corner Fault, with the start being in the corridor formed by the detached buttress and the main wall. A crack system leads you to a face and then wide crack past an old nest. Climb the arête past one bolt to the shuts up and slightly left. Shares anchors with Corner Fault. Climbed ground up without bolt, as with Corner Fault.
content.protection: Trad single rack. Single bolt protects the upper part with poor rock.
content.location: The far right of the wall, see route map.

content.description: Left most climb in the glade area and the first climb set for this area. Done ground up with no idea what the rock quality would be. This route turns out to have the best rock of the area. Start at a blocky crack immediately left of a wide crack (with a tree half way up). Follow a disconnected crack system that veers left and then back right over a slight bulge near the top. Anchors and standard biners at top. Recommend doubles to 1 inch with potential for stopper placement in some of the cracks.
content.location: Far left of Glade Wall -- see route map.

content.description: Start below an obvious left facing corner at the right side of the wall. Climb the crack system to the corner, avoiding the roof by clearing it to the right. Climb the face pass one bolt and head straight up the face, protecting with horizontal placements, to anchors. Tricky gear at the base will make this a difficult on-sight, but it protects well and was therefore not bolted.
content.protection: Trad single rack to 3 inches. One bolt.
content.location: Towards the right of the wall, the left facing corner. See overview route map.

content.description: The beautiful glade that is the centerpiece of this area. West facing rock that is of relatively good quality. A suite of climbs ascend this feature that range from entirely trad protected to a challenging sport route.
